questions.text: A newborn presented with chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The pediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to a deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lecithin (phosphatidylcholine) is the key surfactant component deficient in neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

  • Neonatal Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS), also known as Hyaline Membrane Disease (HMD), is a condition most commonly seen in premature infants born before 34-35 weeks gestation due to a deficiency of pulmonary surfactant.
  • Surfactant is synthesized by type II pneumocytes and reduces surface tension in the alveoli, preventing their collapse during expiration.
  • The primary phospholipid component of surfactant is phosphatidylcholine, commonly known as lecithin, especially in its active form-dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC).
  • Surfactant production starts around 20 weeks of gestation but becomes functionally adequate only after 34-35 weeks.
  • In premature infants, low levels of lecithin lead to alveolar collapse, impaired gas exchange, tissue hypoxia, and formation of a proteinaceous hyaline membrane lining the alveoli.
  • Clinical presentation includes:
    • Tachypnea
    • Chest wall retractions
    • Grunting respiration
    • Cyanosis
    • Decreased air entry
  • Classic X-ray features:
    • Ground-glass opacities due to alveolar atelectasis
    • Air bronchograms
    • Reticulogranular pattern
  • Management involves:
    • NICU admission
    • Supportive care (e.g., IV fluids, oxygen)
    • Surfactant replacement therapy if needed
    • Respiratory support (CPAP or mechanical ventilation)

Explanation of other options:

Dipalmitoyl inositol (Option A): A phospholipid involved in cellular signaling, not a surfactant component, and not relevant to RDS pathophysiology.

Sphingomyelin (Option C): Present in cell membranes and used in the L/S ratio to assess lung maturity, but it does not directly contribute to surfactant function or alveolar stability.

Dipalmitoylphosphatidylethanolamine (Option D): Although it is a membrane phospholipid, it lacks the surface tension-reducing ability of dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (lecithin), which is essential for preventing alveolar collapse.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child weighing 30 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to ISPAD guidelines, initial management of DKA includes airway-breathing-circulation (ABC), fluid resuscitation with 20 mL/kg NS, and delayed insulin initiation after 1 hour.

  • This patient has Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA), as evidenced by severe hyperglycemia (RBS 550 mg/dL), metabolic acidosis (pH 7.01), and ketonuria (urine glucose 3+ with history of dehydration).
  • As per the ISPAD 2022 guidelines, the initial management of DKA in children involves:
    • Airway, Breathing, Circulation (ABC) stabilization
    • Fluid resuscitation with 0.9% Normal Saline 20 mL/kg over 20-30 minutes to restore circulatory volume and begin correcting dehydration.
    • Insulin therapy should not be started immediately.
    • It is initiated after 1 hour of fluid therapy, typically as IV infusion of regular insulin at 0.05 - 0.1 IU/kg/hr.
    • Early insulin without adequate fluid replacement can worsen circulatory collapse and increase the risk of cerebral edema.
  • Other supportive steps:
    • Monitor vitals and GCS hourly.
    • Monitor electrolytes and glucose frequently.
    • Begin potassium replacement once urine output is adequate and insulin is started.
    • Gradually transition to subcutaneous insulin once acidosis resolves (pH > 7.3, HCO3- > 18, BOHB < 1 mmol/L) and oral intake is tolerated.

Reference:

ISPAD 2022: Diabetic ketoacidosis  Page 840,844

Pediatric Diabetic Ketoacidosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4413392/

choices.text: Increase in length of 25 centimetres in the first year
Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
Weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant with a birth weight of 2.8 kg is brought for routine follow-up. The pediatrician wants to assess whether the child is growing appropriately. Which of the following is the best indicator of adequate growth in this infant?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An increase of 25 cm in length during the first year is a reliable indicator of normal growth in infants.

  • Length gain is a consistent and dependable marker of growth.
  • At birth, the average length is approximately 50 cm.
  • By the end of the first year, the child should gain around 25 cm, reaching approximately 75 cm.
  • This increase reflects steady skeletal growth and is less affected by short-term illnesses or feeding issues compared to weight.
  • Other important milestones in height growth include:
    • At 2 years: ~85-90 cm
    • At 4-4.5 years: 100 cm
    • Growth rate: ~6 cm/year from age 2-12 years
    • Height doubles by 4 years and triples by 12 years
  • Weech's formula can be used to estimate weight and height at different ages.

Explanation of other options:

Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year (Option B): Normal weight gain is not consistent throughout infancy. It is about 20-30 grams/day initially, with weight doubling by 5 months and tripling by 12 months. A fixed monthly gain of 300g is underestimated after 3-4 months and doesn't reliably indicate appropriate growth.

Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age (Option C): The anterior fontanelle typically closes between 9 and 18 months. Closure by 6 months may suggest abnormal development (e.g., craniosynostosis) rather than being a normal growth indicator.

Weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile (Option D): Percentile values must be interpreted in the context of serial growth measurements and parental height. A single percentile value does not confirm adequate or inadequate growth unless consistent with previous centiles and trends.

Reference:

https://www.pedgen.org.in/growth.php

https://journals.lww.com/njcp/fulltext/2020/23090/comparison_of_age_based_weight_estimation_with.8.aspx

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classical triad of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) strongly suggests congenital rubella syndrome.

  • Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) occurs when rubella infection is acquired by the mother during early pregnancy, particularly within the first trimester.
  • The virus causes widespread fetal damage through viremia, which is most intense from 10 to 17 days after maternal infection.
  • The risk of congenital defects is highest in the first 12 weeks and significantly decreases after 20 weeks gestation.
  • The characteristic clinical features of CRS include:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) - the most common feature
    • Ocular defects - particularly cataracts (most common), glaucoma, and "salt and pepper" retinopathy
    • Cardiac anomalies - classically patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), followed by pulmonary artery stenosis and ventricular septal defect
    • Other features: microcephaly, intellectual disability, growth retardation, hepatitis, bone lesions, and increased risk of autoimmune conditions like diabetes and thyroid disorders.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with Rubella-specific IgM, PCR for viral RNA, or viral culture.
  • Management is supportive, with no specific antiviral treatment.
  • Prevention is crucial and is achieved through vaccination (MMR/MMRV - live attenuated RA 27/3 strain), which is highly effective (95% after one dose, 99% after two doses).
  • Pregnant women exposed to rubella may be offered immunoglobulin, but it does not reliably prevent fetal infection.

Explanation of other options:

Congenital herpes simplex virus infection (Option A): Typically presents with skin vesicles, chorioretinitis, keratoconjunctivitis, and neurological complications like microcephaly or hydranencephaly. PDA and cataracts are not hallmark features.

Congenital toxoplasmosis (Option B): The classic triad includes chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications, not PDA or cataracts.

Congenital cytomegalovirus infection (Option C): Commonly presents with microcephaly, periventricular calcifications, chorioretinitis, and sensorineural hearing loss, but PDA and cataracts are not typical.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with chronic cough, failure to thrive, and recurrent respiratory infections. On examination, there are crepitations in both lungs. A sweat chloride test is ordered. Which of the following conditions is being evaluated using this test?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Sweat chloride levels are elevated in cystic fibrosis, making it a key diagnostic test for this autosomal recessive disorder.

  • Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene located on chromosome 7q32.
  • The CFTR protein functions as a chloride channel in epithelial cells.
  • A defect in this channel leads to abnormal ion transport, causing thickened secretions in the lungs, pancreas, and other organs.
  • The sweat chloride test is the gold standard diagnostic tool for CF.
  • It is performed using pilocarpine iontophoresis, which stimulates sweat production.
  • The sweat is collected and analyzed for chloride content.
  • Interpretation:
    • Chloride >60 mmol/L in children and adults is diagnostic of CF.
    • 30-59 mmol/L is borderline and requires further testing.
    • <30 mmol/L is generally considered normal.
  • This elevation occurs due to defective chloride reabsorption in sweat ducts. On the other hand, chloride levels are decreased in pancreatic secretions in CF.
  • Additional diagnostic tools include:
    • Genetic testing for common mutations like F508del.
    • Nasal potential difference (NPD) measurement to assess CFTR function.
    • Fecal elastase to evaluate pancreatic function.
    • Chest imaging to assess pulmonary involvement.
    • Serum electrolytes may show hyponatremic, hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to salt loss (known as contraction alkalosis).
    • Transepithelial Intestinal and Rectal Biopsies: These can be used to directly evaluate CFTR function, though they are generally reserved for research or challenging cases.

Explanation of other options:

Phenylketonuria (Option A): Caused by a deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase. Diagnosed by plasma phenylalanine measurement, not sweat chloride.

Gaucher's disease (Option C): A lysosomal storage disorder due to β-glucocerebrosidase deficiency. Diagnosis is made by enzyme assays and genetic testing, not sweat chloride levels.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option D): A disorder of type I collagen synthesis, diagnosed by genetic testing or collagen studies, not sweat chloride analysis.

Reference:

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/5507809_Cystic_fibrosis_in_adults_Diagnostic_and_therapeutic_aspects

https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/cystic-fibrosis

questions.text: A child presents with fever and a rash that begins on the face, particularly behind the ears, cheeks, and buccal mucosa, and then spreads to the rest of the body. On examination, characteristic Koplik's spots are seen on the buccal mucosa.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Koplik's spots along with a descending maculopapular rash and prodromal symptoms confirm the diagnosis of measles.

  • Measles (rubeola) is a highly contagious viral illness caused by an RNA virus of the Paramyxoviridae family.
  • It typically affects children, especially those who are unvaccinated.
  • The classic clinical course involves:
    • Prodrome (3-4 days): High fever, cough, coryza (runny nose), and conjunctivitis-collectively known as the 3 C's.
    • Koplik's spots: These are pathognomonic and appear on the 2nd or 3rd day of illness. They are tiny bluish-white spots with a red halo, typically found on the buccal mucosa opposite the lower molars.
    • Rash (exanthem): Appears on the 4th day of illness, starting behind the ears and spreading to the face, trunk, and limbs in a cephalocaudal pattern. The rash is erythematous, maculopapular, and often confluent.
    • Course: The rash fades in the order it appeared, leaving behind brownish discoloration and fine desquamation.
  • Measles is transmitted via droplet nuclei from respiratory secretions and is contagious from 3 days before to 4 days after the onset of rash.
  • Management is mainly supportive, with antipyretics, hydration, and vitamin A supplementation.

Explanation of other options:

Rubella (Option B): Rubella also causes a maculopapular rash that begins on the face and spreads, but it is milder, non-confluent, and often associated with postauricular and occipital lymphadenopathy. Forchheimer spots (rose-colored spots on the soft palate) may be seen, not Koplik's spots.

Varicella (Option C): Caused by the varicella-zoster virus, it presents with a pruritic rash appearing in crops at different stages (macules → papules → vesicles → crusts), typically starting on the trunk. Koplik's spots are not seen in varicella.

Mumps (Option D): Caused by a paramyxovirus, mumps presents with parotitis, fever, and sometimes orchitis or meningitis. A rash is uncommon, and Koplik's spots are absent.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with a cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. The total leukocyte count is >50,000 cells/μL. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Azithromycin is the first-line treatment for pertussis in all age groups, including infants under 1 month.

  • The clinical presentation of paroxysmal cough, apnea, and marked leukocytosis (>50,000 cells/μL) in a 3-week-old infant is highly suggestive of pertussis (whooping cough), a respiratory infection caused by Bordetella pertussis.
  • The illness progresses in three stages:
    • Catarrhal stage (1-2 weeks): mild URI symptoms
    • Paroxysmal stage (2-6 weeks): paroxysmal coughing with characteristic "whoop", post-tussive vomiting, and apnea in infants
    • Convalescent stage (1-4 weeks): gradual recovery
  • Pertussis can be dangerous in infants and may lead to pulmonary hypertension, cardiogenic shock, hemorrhage, seizures, and malnutrition.
  • Azithromycin is the drug of choice across all age groups due to its safety and efficacy.
  • It eradicates the bacteria from the nasopharynx and helps reduce the risk of transmission.
  • In infants <1 month old, erythromycin and clarithromycin are contraindicated because of the risk of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).
  • Cotrimoxazole is also contraindicated in infants <2 months due to the risk of kernicterus.
  • Early treatment, preferably in the catarrhal stage, improves outcomes and reduces infectivity.
  • Infants with confirmed or suspected pertussis should also be isolated for at least 5 days after starting antibiotics.
  • Preventive measures include the DTaP vaccine for infants and Tdap vaccination during pregnancy (ideally between 27-36 weeks) to confer passive immunity to the newborn.

Explanation of other options:

Amoxicillin (Option B): Not effective against Bordetella pertussis; it targets gram-positive organisms, not the gram-negative coccobacilli responsible for pertussis.

Cotrimoxazole (Option C): Though it is an alternative in older children or adults allergic to macrolides, it is contraindicated in infants <2 months due to the risk of kernicterus.

Clarithromycin (Option D): Also effective against B. pertussis, but contraindicated in infants <1 month due to the risk of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK519008/

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. The radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) presents with biphasic stridor and a characteristic "steeple sign" on X-ray due to subglottic narrowing.

  • Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup) is a viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions of the airway.
  • Causative agents:
    • Most common: Parainfluenza viruses (types 1, 2, and 3) - ~75% of cases.
    • Other viruses:
      • Influenza A and B
      • Adenovirus
      • Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV)
      • Measles virus
  • Common in children aged 3 months to 5 years.
  • Peak incidence: 2nd year of life.
  • Initial Symptoms (last 1-3 days before airway obstruction)
    • Upper respiratory tract infection signs:
      • Rhinorrhea
      • Pharyngitis
      • Mild cough
      • Low-grade fever
    • Progressive symptoms:
      • Barking (seal-like) cough
      • Hoarseness
      • Inspiratory stridor
      • Fever (up to 39-40°C, or may be absent)
      • Child prefers sitting upright
      • Symptoms worse at night, recur over days, and resolve in a week
  • Physical examination findings:
    • Hoarse voice
    • Coryza
    • Mild-to-moderate pharyngeal inflammation
    • Slightly increased respiratory rate
    • Hypoxia/low SpO2 in severe airway obstruction
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical diagnosis based on history and exam
    • X-ray (PA neck): Steeple sign (subglottic narrowing)
  • Treatment:
    • Main goals: Airway management and hypoxia control
    • Mild Croup: Single dose of oral dexamethasone (0.6 mg/kg; 0.15 mg/kg may also be effective)
    • Moderate to Severe Croup
      • Nebulized racemic epinephrine + dexamethasone
      • Used in stridor at rest, respiratory distress, or hypoxia
      • May prevent need for intubation
    • Corticosteroids
      • Reduce laryngeal mucosal edema
      • Beneficial even in mild cases
    • Antibiotics: Not indicated (viral etiology)

Explanation of other options:

Acute epiglottitis (Option A): Presents acutely with high fever, drooling, dysphagia, and toxic appearance. The child often sits in a "tripod" position. Radiograph shows the thumb sign due to swollen epiglottis.

Foreign body aspiration (Option C): Sudden onset of cough, gagging, wheeze, or unilateral decreased breath sounds-not typically biphasic stridor. Chest X-ray may show air trapping or radiopaque objects.

Laryngomalacia (Option D): A congenital anomaly with chronic inspiratory stridor starting in early infancy, worsens with crying or feeding. Diagnosis is made by laryngoscopy, showing an omega-shaped epiglottis.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441873/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK431070/

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents to the pediatric OPD with complaints of persistent jaundice and pale (clay-colored) stools. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. Laboratory investigations show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and liver biopsy reveals periductal proliferation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Biliary atresia presents in infancy with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, clay-colored stools, and shows periductal proliferation on liver biopsy.

  • Biliary atresia is a progressive fibro-obliterative disease of the extrahepatic biliary tree, often presenting in the first 2-6 weeks of life.
  • The key clinical features include:
    • Persistent jaundice
    • Acholic (clay-colored) stools
    • Dark urine
  • The histological hallmark is periductal fibrosis and bile duct proliferation, seen on liver biopsy.
  • Types:
    • Perinatal type (70%): No associated anomalies
    • BASM syndrome (15%): Includes Biliary atresia, Asplenia/polysplenia, Situs inversus, and other anomalies
    • Other syndromic associations (15%): Choledochal cysts, renal malformations
  • Investigations:
    • LFTs: Elevated conjugated bilirubin and cholestatic enzymes (ALP, GGT, 5'-nucleotidase)
    • Ultrasound: Absent gallbladder, "triangular cord sign"
    • HIDA scan: No tracer excretion despite phenobarbitone priming
    • Liver biopsy: Gold standard, shows periductal fibrosis and bile duct proliferation
    • Exploratory laparotomy with intraoperative cholangiogram: Confirmatory test
  • Management:
    • Kasai portoenterostomy (hepaticojejunostomy) within 8 weeks
    • Definitive treatment: Liver transplant

Explanation of other options:

Crigler-Najjar syndrome (Option A): Caused by glucuronyl transferase deficiency → results in unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. No periductal changes on biopsy.

Rotor syndrome (Option B): Caused by defects in hepatic organic anion transporters (SLCO1B1/1B3) → mild conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with normal liver histology.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome (Option C): Mutation in MRP2 gene → benign conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The liver appears black grossly due to pigment deposition, but no bile duct proliferation.

Reference:

https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/liverextrahepaticbiliaryatresia.html

questions.text: An infant presents with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia. Neuroimaging with CT shows periventricular calcifications. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Periventricular calcifications with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia are hallmark features of congenital CMV infection.

  • Congenital CMV infection is the most common congenital viral infection and occurs via in utero transmission, especially during primary maternal infection.
  • The transmission risk increases with gestational age, though the severity is higher in early infection.
  • Approximately 90% of infected infants are asymptomatic, while 10% show symptomatic features, including:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Petechiae or purpura (blueberry muffin appearance)
    • Jaundice (direct hyperbilirubinemia)
    • Microcephaly
    • Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Periventricular calcifications on CT, which are pathognomonic
    • Sensorineural hearing loss is the most common long-term complication
  • Diagnosis requires confirmation within the first 2–3 weeks of life using PCR for CMV DNA in urine or saliva.
    • IgG is not diagnostic due to maternal antibody transfer; IgM is unreliable alone.
  • Management includes:
    • Ganciclovir (IV) for symptomatic neonates, particularly those with CNS involvement.
    • Regular follow-up with hearing assessments, developmental screening, and vision monitoring.

Causes of Blueberry Muffin Rash:

Explanation of other options:

Congenital rubella syndrome (Option A): Characterized by the classic triad of sensorineural deafness, cataracts, and congenital heart defects (notably PDA). Also features salt-and-pepper retinopathy, not periventricular calcification.

Congenital herpes simplex virus infection (Option B): Manifests with vesicular skin lesions, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly/hydranencephaly. CT may show diffuse cerebral involvement, not specifically periventricular calcification.

Congenital toxoplasmosis (Option C): Presents with the triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications. Unlike CMV, calcifications in toxoplasmosis are diffuse and random, not periventricular.

Reference:

https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Causes-of-blueberry-muffin-rash_tbl1_353975855
